name: Moderator Bill Gottschalk
comment info:
Thanks to all teachers and students who responded.   Lots of thoughtful noticing and wondering.  Jett from Brooklyn wrote this headline: “Immigrants Search for a Better Life for Their Young.”  What’s your headline?  You can continue to post responses. Dig deeper into these graphs. Please check back tomorrow afternoon, Thursday Dec. 6, to see the Reveal with a link to the original New York Times article, some questions about the graphs, and three Stat Nuggets.
 
The next graph will be released tomorrow -- THURSDAY, DEC. 6, with moderation on WEDNESDAY, DEC. 12!    It tries to answer the question: “Do some running shoes make you run faster?”  You may respond before, during, or after the live moderation by running, jogging, or just walking to What's Going On In This Graph? 

Signing off – Sharon Hessney in Boston, who has had many students who are Dreamers, and Bill Gottschalk in Collinsville, who’s from the third largest Dreamer state.

name: Moderator Bill Gottschalk
comment info:
Hi everyone,

I'll be responding to comments for the next 2.5 hours.  One thing I noticed is that Dreamers are relatively young.  I wondered if the parents of these Dreamers wanted a better life for their children at an earlier age, so they waited until their children were more mobile and not babies to get them across the border.

replies.name: M

HI, @Nate Decker –
You bring up a very interesting point.  Maybe the population size of a state affects the number of Dreamers in the state.  If you go to the Homeland Security data (https://tinyurl.com/2018DACAdata), there is an Excel document with DACA data by state.  You could use this to calculate the number of DACA recipients per 1,000 state residents.  (You can limit your work to some or all of the top 14 states in the graph.)  Then, you will have evidence if it is “easier to blend into a state.”  Let us know what you find out.

name: Moderator Sharon
comment info:
Welcome to Wednesday's moderation of  “What’s Going On in This Graph?”  Today’s graphs show who are the  'Dreamers' -- Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) recipients.  From 9 am – 2 pm E.T. today, give us your responses online to these three questions -- "What do you notice?",  "What do you wonder?", and  "What's going on in this graph?"  Plus, share with us a catchy headline. On Thursday afternoon, we’ll reveal the article that included these graphs and much more.  We look forward to reading your discoveries.
(The next “What’s Going On in This Graph?” will be released tomorrow -- Thursday, Dec. 6 with moderation on Wednesday, December 12.  The topic -- fastest running shoes.)

name: Lucy F.
comment info: We were given this graph without any context of what it was, so at first it was very confusing. I noticed the source said "U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services," so then I got the concept of the graph and could make further observations. The bars colored yellow exhibit the largest amounts of whatever it's measuring. I wondered why only these states were included; were these states the ones who most experience immigration? I also asked why the graph went up to 15 years old, but then I figured that the age that would determine someone as a child would be 15 and under, therefore, the information from this graph wouldn't be prevalent. The data also demonstrates that the older the child is, the less DACA benefits them. My catchy headline would be: "Immigration Into Our Nation."

replies.name: M
replies.comment info:
Hi, @Lucy F. –
Thank you for all of your thoughtful response.  Your last comment questions why the bar graph by age stops at 15 years old.  Read below the graphs.  There is an explanation about who was eligible for DACA.  This will answer your question.  
Keep noticing and wondering!

name: Noah
comment info: When looking at the graph, I noticed that California is way ahead of all the other states by a wide margin. I also noticed that in the percent of DACA beneficiaries, the age of three years old had the highest number. I wondered about the connections between these two pieces of information. Where are the other states? Why were there were only 14 included? Also, I wondered why the data was not displayed with a circle graph since it was showing percentages?

replies.name: M
replies.comment info:
HI, @Noah—
You raise the question “Why were there only 14 (states) included?  Take a look at the source of the date -- U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Service, Department of Homeland Security.  There is also a summary table in Governing Magazine (http://www.governing.com/gov-data/other/daca-approved-participants-by-state.html). 
Regarding displaying the data in a circle graph (or pie chart), imagine if there were 14 “slices of pie” with this data.  Or better yet, make a pie chart with the data.  What does it look like?  How easy would it be to read?  Alternatively, how might you use the data from the bar graph to make a more usable pie chart?

replies.name: M
replies.comment info:
HI, @G.McBride--
You've pointed out an interesting point about the occupation table.  DACA eligible workers have a greater percentage of professional and office-type jobs.  You surmise that maybe this is due to getting more education.  Would you please “noodle” about your headline and make it shorter for a newspaper article?

name: Maddie
comment info:
DACA Data Differences

While interpreting this graph, I noticed that they only displayed data for 14 states. Not only are there only 14 states included on this graph, but all of the states share something in common; they all have large cities. Although all these states have large cities, I wonder where the data for the other 36 states are, and why they aren't displayed. In particular, I am interested about Wisconsin.

replies.name: M
replies.comment info:
HI, @Maddie –
You raised the same question as Noah did.  Take a look at the reply I gave to him.  Why do you think that the designers of the graph stopped at 14 states?  What would you recommend and why?

HI, @Abby –

name: Sofia L.
comment info:
I noticed that California and Texas have the largest number of DACA children. This makes sense, since America's largest influx of immigrants are coming from Mexico and Central America as of late. I also observed that 3-year-olds make up the largest individual group benefitted by this program. This makes sense for families who want to immigrate ASAP but can't deal with the needs of a baby. Especially in illegal cases- toddlers can walk on their own if needed and can be reasoned with if their parents need them to stay quiet.
I wonder why these particular states are pictured on this graph- past New York they seem to be almost random. Does DACA have better/larger facilities in these states? Did their governments make a special agreement?
My catchy headline would be: "DACA Dreamers: What really happens to America's young immigrants?"

name: Lucy A
comment info: What I notice about the graph is that not all the states appear in the graph. This makes me wonder if there is a specific type of states that are in the graph. name: G.McBride
comment info:
I noticed that the largest number of DACA participants come from the two most populous border states of California and Texas. California is almost 100k more than Texas and Texas is more than double Illinois. This is, however, unsurprising because they are on the border and they both have large economies that can offer plenty of job opportunities. I also noticed that the largest age group at entry was at 3 yrs, but between 1 yr and 7 yrs the percentage remained fairly steady, but starts to steadily decline after age 7. 

I wonder what countries these DACA participants represent in each state? I would guess mostly Mexico and Central America, but I'm sure other countries must be represented as well. Possibly Cuba, Middle Eastern countries, South America,  African countries, and Asia? I wonder if the decline in the older age of entry is because older children are already established in their country of residence and it makes it harder for them to pack up and leave?

A headline is "With more immigrants comes more DACA beneficiaries" This is because I noticed that these states listed have the highest immigrant population.

name: Mackenzie
comment info: I noticed that the graph is a negative slope meaning that the dependent variable slowly decreases. Another thing that I noticed was that there were two different colors of the bars on the graph then I realized that the yellow bars were the highest number which I found very interesting which were the highest. Something that I wondered was what is data for other states? I would be very interested to learn about data from my state(Wisconsin). Another questioned that I wondered was why is it the most common for the age of entry to be younger? For my catchy headline, I was able to come up with was The Astonishing Data of Dreamers.

name: Max M
comment info: I noticed that many of the states with big cities had a higher number of DACA beneficiaries than the states with smaller cities. I was wondering what percent of jobs in the big cities like San Francisco, Los Angeles, or Dallas are filled by DACA beneficiaries. I am interested to know this because the age of entry is quite young. Could this mean they could be working as teenagers or even younger? The information from the chart only included workers aged 16-32.

name: Max Watchmaker
comment info: I looked at the DACA dreames and I noticed that states with big cities such as California or Illinois have a lot of DACA benficiares.  I also noticed that most of the states with a lot of beneficaires are along the coasts.  I wonder why aren't all of the states included in this graph.  Is that because they have so few or not?  I also am wondering why most of the immigrants are so young.

name: Eloise Hayden
comment info: While reading this article, I noticed that there is a lot of information about ages. I also noticed that the bigger cities had more DACA beneficiaries than smaller cities. I wonder what type of things DACA provides, such as jobs, food, clothes, homes, and more. Does DACA provide any money for them?

name: Evelyn Grahama
comment info: I noticed that in the first graph, only 14 states where included. I was wondering what the data was for the other 36 states and if they and their data were included in the third graph?

name: Zander
comment info: I was looking at the DACA dreamers graph and I wonder what makes a state less occurring to immigration. Does the border states have a greater chance to receive them because they are on the edge of our country? Does it have to do with the distance of the state?

replies.name: M
replies.comment info:
HI, @Zander –
That’s a good question – Do border states have more DACA recipients that states far from the border?  
You could use this Homeland Security data (https://tinyurl.com/2018DACAdata) to answer your question.  (You may want to adjust the numbers of the population of each state.) Please share your findings.

name: Jackson
comment info:
Some thoughts on DACA graphs.
Some things I noticed and wondered about this graph after looking at it include, what is DACA? Why are all of the states not included, I am interested to know what Wisconsin would be at compared to the other states. There are large immigrations from Mexico, California and Texas are semi-close to the southern border of the U.S, does this have anything to do with CA. and TX. Some of the things I noticed are the huge gap between CA TX and IL. Why is there a 100,000 person gap? The graph is a bar graph, but it is a little bit intresting because it is at a rotation that most of us aren't used to seeing. What could this graph be titled?

replies.name: M
replies.comment info:
HI, @Jackson –
Search online for DACA by state and you will see how many Dreamers are in Wisconsin.  How many are there?  What percentage of the Wisconsin population is this?  I took a look and see almost half are in the Milwaukee area.  Why do you think this is so?

name: SDCI PIVOT
comment info: We looked at the stats on the DACA dreamers and were wondering what makes someone ineligible for a certain job (we tried to research this but came up empty). We noticed that many of the states that the DACA dreamers entered are on the coasts. We wondered how the dreamers are coping with the uncertainty surrounding their status. We are wondering why the dreamers had to be a certain age (have to have arrived by 2007 and under 16).

replies.name: M
replies.comment info:
HI, @ SDCI PIVOT—
Thank you for your response right out of the box on Friday.  
You can find some summary information on DACA in the New York Times article “What Does the Latest Court Ruling on DACA Mean?” This article answers some of the frequently asked questions and has a 3-minute video of Dreamers, many your age, telling us what they have gained from DACA.  There are additional resources in the Reveal, which we release on Thursday afternoon.
May I ask you a question.  Does Canada have individuals who were brought into Canada as children and now find themselves unauthorized immigrants?
